message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Behavioural ecology at the spatial–social interface
Paper Abstract: ABSTRACT Spatial and social behaviour are fundamental aspects of an animal's biology, and their social and spatial environments are indelibly linked through mutual causes and shared consequences. We define the ‘spatial–social interface’ as intersection of social and spatial aspects of individuals' phenotypes and environments. Behavioural variation at the spatial–social interface has implications for ecological and evolutionary processes including pathogen transmission, population dynamics, and the evolution of social systems. We link spatial and social processes through a foundation of shared theory, vocabulary, and methods. We provide examples and future directions for the integration of spatial and social behaviour and environments. We introduce key concepts and approaches that either implicitly or explicitly integrate social and spatial processes, for example, graph theory, density‐dependent habitat selection, and niche specialization. Finally, we discuss how movement ecology helps link the spatial–social interface. Our review integrates social and spatial behavioural ecology and identifies testable hypotheses at the spatial–social interface.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of population dynamics:

## Definition

Population dynamics is the type of mathematics used to model and study the size and age composition of populations as dynamical systems.(no content)Population dynamics is a branch of mathematical biology, and uses mathematical techniques such as differential equations to model behaviour.

## Basic Principles

Population dynamics describes the ways in which a given population grows and shrinks over time, as controlled by birth, death, and migration.(no content)Simplified population models usually start with four key variables (four demographic processes) including death, birth, immigration, and emigration.

## Historical Development

The beginning of population dynamics is widely regarded as the work of Malthus, formulated as the Malthusian growth model.(no content)One of the most basic and milestone models of population growth was the logistic model of population growth formulated by Pierre François Verhulst in 1838. The logistic model takes the shape of a sigmoid curve and describes the growth of a population as exponential, followed by a decrease in growth, and bound by a carrying capacity due to environmental pressures.

## Applications

Population models are used to determine maximum harvest for agriculturists, to understand the dynamics of biological invasions, and for environmental conservation. Population models are also used to understand the spread of parasites, viruses, and disease.

Links: [{"title":"Population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics"},{"title":"Pest insect population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pest_insect_population_dynamics"},{"title":"Population dynamics of fisheries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics_of_fisheries"},{"title":"Population model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_model"},{"title":"Population ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_ecology"},{"title":"Matrix population models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_population_models"},{"title":"Source–sink dynamics","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source–sink_dynamics"},{"title":"Malthusian growth model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malthusian_growth_model"},{"title":"Metapopulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metapopulation"},{"title":"León Mario Bedoya - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_Mario_Bedoya"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of population dynamics:

## Definition

Population dynamics is the type of mathematics used to model and study the size and age composition of populations as dynamical systems.(no content)Population dynamics is a branch of mathematical biology, and uses mathematical techniques such as differential equations to model behaviour.

## Basic Principles

Population dynamics describes the ways in which a given population grows and shrinks over time, as controlled by birth, death, and migration.(no content)Simplified population models usually start with four key variables (four demographic processes) including death, birth, immigration, and emigration.

## Historical Development

The beginning of population dynamics is widely regarded as the work of Malthus, formulated as the Malthusian growth model.(no content)One of the most basic and milestone models of population growth was the logistic model of population growth formulated by Pierre François Verhulst in 1838. The logistic model takes the shape of a sigmoid curve and describes the growth of a population as exponential, followed by a decrease in growth, and bound by a carrying capacity due to environmental pressures.

## Applications

Population models are used to determine maximum harvest for agriculturists, to understand the dynamics of biological invasions, and for environmental conservation. Population models are also used to understand the spread of parasites, viruses, and disease.

Web search results for query: "Social behaviour ecology"

Links: [{"title":"Behavioral ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_ecology"},{"title":"Human behavioral ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_behavioral_ecology"},{"title":"Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_Ecology_and_Sociobiology"},{"title":"Behavioral Ecology (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_Ecology_(journal)"},{"title":"Social ecology (academic field) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_ecology_(academic_field)"},{"title":"Social ecological model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_ecological_model"},{"title":"Sociobiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociobiology"},{"title":"Socio-ecological system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socio-ecological_system"},{"title":"Social ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_ecology"},{"title":"Ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about social behaviour ecology:

## Overview

Behavioral ecology is the study of the evolutionary basis for animal behavior due to ecological pressures. When examining social behavior specifically, ecology, social conflicts, and life history differences are the primary factors influencing differences within and between species.

## Social Behavior Concepts

Cooperation in social organisms has numerous ecological factors that can determine the benefits and costs associated with this form of organization. For example, one suggested benefit is a type of "life insurance" for individuals who participate in the care of the young, where individuals may have a greater likelihood of transmitting genes to the next generation when helping in a group compared to individual reproduction.(no content)The value of a social behavior depends in part on the social behavior of an animal's neighbors; for example, the more likely a rival male is to back down from a threat, the more value a male gets out of making the threat.

## Evolutionary Game Theory

When a population exhibits a number of interacting social behaviors, it can evolve a stable pattern of behaviors known as an evolutionarily stable strategy (ESS), where only strategies that cannot be "invaded" by alternative mutant strategies are maintained in the population.

## Related Field: Sociobiology

Sociobiology is based on the premise that some behaviors are at least partly inherited and can be affected by natural selection, and seeks to explain behavior as a product of natural selection.

Links: [{"title":"Graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory"},{"title":"Network theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_theory"},{"title":"Connectivity (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connectivity_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"Glossary of graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_graph_theory"},{"title":"Network neuroscience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_neuroscience"},{"title":"Circuit topology (electrical) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circuit_topology_(electrical)"},{"title":"Centrality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centrality"}]

I've completed a web search for "Graph theory networks." Here's a summary of the key information:

## Overview

In mathematics, computer science, and network science, network theory is a part of graph theory.(no content)Graph theory is the study of graphs, systems of nodes or vertices connected in pairs by lines or edges.

## Definition of Networks

Networks are defined as graphs where the vertices or edges possess attributes.(no content)Network science is an academic field which studies complex networks such as telecommunication networks, computer networks, biological networks, cognitive and semantic networks, and social networks.

## Key Applications

Graph theory networks have diverse applications across multiple fields:

- **Computer Science**: Within computer science, linked structures are graphs that are used to represent networks of communication, data organization, computational devices, the flow of computation, etc.

- **Social Networks**: Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory.

- **Biology and Medicine**: Graph-based methods are used to model genes or proteins in a pathway and study the relationships between them, such as metabolic pathways and gene regulatory networks.

- **Other Fields**: Network theory has applications in many disciplines, including statistical physics, particle physics, computer science, electrical engineering, biology, archaeology, linguistics, economics, finance, operations research, climatology, ecology, public health, sociology, psychology, and neuroscience. Applications include logistical networks, the World Wide Web, Internet, gene regulatory networks, and metabolic networks.

Web search results for query: "Pathogen transmission disease"

Links: [{"title":"Pathogen transmission - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogen_transmission"},{"title":"Pathogen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogen"},{"title":"Epidemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic"},{"title":"Zoonosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoonosis"},{"title":"Human pathogen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_pathogen"},{"title":"Airborne transmission - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airborne_transmission"},{"title":"Infection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infection"},{"title":"Natural reservoir - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_reservoir"},{"title":"Disease vector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disease_vector"},{"title":"Vertically transmitted infection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertically_transmitted_infection"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of pathogen transmission disease:

## What is Pathogen Transmission?

In medicine, public health, and biology, transmission is the passing of a pathogen causing communicable disease from an infected host individual or group to a particular individual or group, regardless of whether the other individual was previously infected.

## Main Routes of Transmission

Transmission of pathogens can occur by direct contact, through contaminated food, body fluids or objects, by airborne inhalation or through vector organisms. More specifically, the major transmission routes include:

- **Airborne Transmission**: Very small dry and wet particles that stay in the air for long periods of time allowing airborne contamination even after the departure of the host.

- **Droplet Transmission**: Small and usually wet particles that stay in the air for a short period of time. Contamination usually occurs in the presence of the host.

- **Direct Contact**: Touching an infected individual, including sexual contact

- **Indirect Contact**: Indirect contact transmission, also known as vehicle-borne transmission, involves transmission through contamination of inanimate objects. Vehicles that may indirectly transmit an infectious agent include food, water, biologic products such as blood, and fomites such as handkerchiefs, bedding, or surgical scalpels.

- **Vector-Borne**: A vector is an organism that does not cause disease itself but that transmits infection by conveying pathogens from one host to another.

## Key Concepts

The term infectivity describes the ability of an organism to enter, survive and multiply in the host, while the infectiousness of a disease agent indicates the comparative ease with which the disease agent is transmitted to other hosts.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of pathogen transmission disease:

## What is Pathogen Transmission?

In medicine, public health, and biology, transmission is the passing of a pathogen causing communicable disease from an infected host individual or group to a particular individual or group, regardless of whether the other individual was previously infected.

## Main Routes of Transmission

Transmission of pathogens can occur by direct contact, through contaminated food, body fluids or objects, by airborne inhalation or through vector organisms. More specifically, the major transmission routes include:

- **Airborne Transmission**: Very small dry and wet particles that stay in the air for long periods of time allowing airborne contamination even after the departure of the host.

- **Droplet Transmission**: Small and usually wet particles that stay in the air for a short period of time. Contamination usually occurs in the presence of the host.

- **Direct Contact**: Touching an infected individual, including sexual contact

- **Indirect Contact**: Indirect contact transmission, also known as vehicle-borne transmission, involves transmission through contamination of inanimate objects. Vehicles that may indirectly transmit an infectious agent include food, water, biologic products such as blood, and fomites such as handkerchiefs, bedding, or surgical scalpels.

- **Vector-Borne**: A vector is an organism that does not cause disease itself but that transmits infection by conveying pathogens from one host to another.

## Key Concepts

The term infectivity describes the ability of an organism to enter, survive and multiply in the host, while the infectiousness of a disease agent indicates the comparative ease with which the disease agent is transmitted to other hosts.

Links: [{"title":"Spatial ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_ecology"},{"title":"Theoretical ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical_ecologist"},{"title":"Group living - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_living"},{"title":"Behavioral geography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_geography"},{"title":"Spatial organization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_organization"},{"title":"Ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology"},{"title":"Collective animal behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_animal_behavior"},{"title":"Interspecific competition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interspecific_competition"},{"title":"Animal geography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_geography"},{"title":"Animal Behaviour (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_Behaviour_(journal)"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of spatial behaviour in animal ecology:

## Spatial Ecology and Spatial Patterns

Spatial ecology studies the ultimate distributional or spatial unit occupied by a species.(no content)In nature, organisms are neither distributed uniformly nor at random, forming instead some sort of spatial pattern due to various energy inputs, disturbances, and species interactions that result in spatially patchy structures or gradients.

## Spatial Niche and Competition

In a particular habitat shared by several species, each of the species is usually confined to its own microhabitat or spatial niche because two species in the same general territory cannot usually occupy the same ecological niche for any significant length of time.(no content)In some cases, niche differentiation results in spatial displacement, where species avoid direct competition by occupying different areas.

## Group Living and Spatial Proximity

A fundamental characteristic of group living is that individuals need to show spatial proximity over time to be considered a group, with the working definition of group living being where two or more individuals display a degree of spatial proximity over time.

## Spatial Organization Within Groups

Spatial organization can be observed when components of an abiotic or biological group are arranged non-randomly in space.(no content)Individuals in biological groups may be arranged non-randomly due to selfish behavior, dominance interactions, or cooperative behavior.

## Behavioral Ecology

Behavioural ecology is the study of an organism's behaviour in its environment and its ecological and evolutionary implications.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about movement ecology and animal movement:

## Movement Ecology

Movement ecology encompasses various aspects including dispersal and long-distance dispersal, migration, foraging, navigation, flight aerodynamics, animal behavior, social interactions, invasive species, disease spread by avian species, gene flow, and plant-animal interactions.(no content)Movement Ecology is a free-access journal published by BioMed Central, which serves as a major forum for research in this field.

## Animal Movement

Animal locomotion is any of a variety of methods that animals use to move from one place to another, with some modes being self-propelled such as running, swimming, jumping, flying, hopping, soaring and gliding.(no content)Animals move for a variety of reasons, such as to find food, a mate, a suitable microhabitat, or to escape predators. For many animals, the ability to move is essential for survival, and natural selection has shaped the locomotion methods used by moving organisms.

## Animal Migration

Migration in ecology is the large-scale movement of members of a species to a different environment.(no content)Animal migration is the relatively long-distance movement of individual animals, usually on a seasonal basis.(no content)The cause of migration may be local climate, local availability of food, the season of the year or for mating.

## Research and Tracking

Animal migration tracking is used in wildlife biology, conservation biology, ecology, and wildlife management to study animals' behavior in the wild.

Web search results for query: "Niche specialization ecology"

Links: [{"title":"Ecological niche - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_niche"},{"title":"Generalist and specialist species - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalist_and_specialist_species"},{"title":"Organizational ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_ecology"},{"title":"Niche construction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niche_construction"},{"title":"Functional group (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_group_(ecology)"},{"title":"Category:Ecological niche - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ecological_niche"},{"title":"Realized niche width - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Realized_niche_width"},{"title":"Species distribution modelling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species_distribution_modelling"},{"title":"Evolutionary ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_Ecology"},{"title":"Eltonian niche - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eltonian_niche"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of niche specialization in ecology:

## What is Niche Specialization?

A specialist species can thrive only in a narrow range of environmental conditions or has a limited diet. This contrasts with generalist species, which can adapt to diverse environments and resources.

## Key Characteristics of Specialized Species

A species with a highly specialized ecological niche is more effective at competing with other organisms.(no content)A benefit of a specialist species is that because the species has a more clearly defined niche, this reduces competition from other species.

However, specialization comes with trade-offs. When environmental conditions change, generalists are able to adapt, but specialists tend to fall victim to extinction much more easily.

## Examples of Specialization

Some well-known examples include: The threatened monarch butterfly exclusively lays its eggs on milkweed species.(no content)A well-known example of a specialist animal is the monophagous koala, which subsists almost entirely on eucalyptus leaves.(no content)It is estimated that about half of native US bee species are pollen specialists, meaning they collect resources from specific genera.

## The Spectrum of Specialization

Most organisms do not all fit neatly into either group. Some species are highly specialized (the most extreme case being monophagous, eating one specific type of food), others less so, and some can tolerate many different environments. In other words, there is a continuum from highly specialized to broadly generalist species.

Web search results for query: "Niche specialization ecology"

Links: [{"title":"Ecological niche - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_niche"},{"title":"Generalist and specialist species - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalist_and_specialist_species"},{"title":"Organizational ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizational_ecology"},{"title":"Niche construction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niche_construction"},{"title":"Functional group (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_group_(ecology)"},{"title":"Category:Ecological niche - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ecological_niche"},{"title":"Realized niche width - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Realized_niche_width"},{"title":"Species distribution modelling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species_distribution_modelling"},{"title":"Evolutionary ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_Ecology"},{"title":"Eltonian niche - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eltonian_niche"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of niche specialization in ecology:

## What is Niche Specialization?

A specialist species can thrive only in a narrow range of environmental conditions or has a limited diet. This contrasts with generalist species, which can adapt to diverse environments and resources.

## Key Characteristics of Specialized Species

A species with a highly specialized ecological niche is more effective at competing with other organisms.(no content)A benefit of a specialist species is that because the species has a more clearly defined niche, this reduces competition from other species.

However, specialization comes with trade-offs. When environmental conditions change, generalists are able to adapt, but specialists tend to fall victim to extinction much more easily.

## Examples of Specialization

Some well-known examples include: The threatened monarch butterfly exclusively lays its eggs on milkweed species.(no content)A well-known example of a specialist animal is the monophagous koala, which subsists almost entirely on eucalyptus leaves.(no content)It is estimated that about half of native US bee species are pollen specialists, meaning they collect resources from specific genera.

## The Spectrum of Specialization

Most organisms do not all fit neatly into either group. Some species are highly specialized (the most extreme case being monophagous, eating one specific type of food), others less so, and some can tolerate many different environments. In other words, there is a continuum from highly specialized to broadly generalist species.

Web search results for query: "Habitat selection density dependent"

Links: [{"title":"Isodar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isodar"},{"title":"Frequency-dependent selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency-dependent_selection"},{"title":"Density dependence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Density_dependence"},{"title":"Habitat-selection hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habitat-selection_hypothesis"},{"title":"Biological dispersal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_dispersal"},{"title":"Spatial ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_ecology"},{"title":"Species distribution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species_distribution"},{"title":"Delayed density dependence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delayed_density_dependence"},{"title":"Eastern meadow vole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_meadow_vole"},{"title":"Fitness-density covariance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness-density_covariance"}]

Based on the web search results, here are the key findings about habitat selection and density-dependent processes:

## Isodar Theory

An isodar is a theory in evolutionary ecology developed in the late 1980s by Douglas W. Morris.(no content)Isodars model density-dependent habitat selection for one or two species in two habitats according to the ideal free and ideal despotic distributions.(no content)Isodars can be used to study density-dependent habitat selection between two species competing for two habitats, with species equilibrating between the two habitats to maintain equal fitness within their own species and avoid competition with the other species.

## Practical Applications

Ideal free isodars predict that a species density in habitat A will increase linearly with its density in habitat B so that each individual in the species has the same fitness.

## Fitness-Density Covariance

Another related concept is fitness-density covariance, which demonstrates density-dependent habitat selection in action. When a species becomes very rare, its population will shift to predominantly locations with favorable conditions (e.g., less competition or good habitat), and when a species becomes very common, conditions will worsen where they are most common, and they will spread into areas where conditions are less favorable.

These mechanisms allow animals to adjust their habitat use based on population density, helping species avoid excessive competition and optimize their fitness across different habitat types.

Web search results for query: "Social systems evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Sociocultural evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociocultural_evolution"},{"title":"Social evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_evolution"},{"title":"Social system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_system"},{"title":"Social effects of evolutionary theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_effects_of_evolutionary_theory"},{"title":"Unilineal evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unilineal_evolution"},{"title":"Social structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_structure"},{"title":"Sociocybernetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociocybernetics"},{"title":"Punctuated equilibrium in social theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punctuated_equilibrium_in_social_theory"},{"title":"Origins of society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Origins_of_society"},{"title":"Systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_theory"}]

I found comprehensive information about social systems evolution. Here's an overview of the key findings:

## Overview of Social Systems Evolution

In sociology, a social system is the patterned network of relationships constituting a coherent whole that exist between individuals, groups, and institutions.(no content)Examples of social systems include nuclear family units, communities, cities, nations, college campuses, religions, corporations, and industries.

## Historical Theories

### Sociocultural Evolution
Most of the 19th-century and some 20th-century approaches to socioculture aimed to provide models for the evolution of humankind as a whole, with the work of Talcott Parsons operating on a scale which included a theory of world history.(no content)Parsons divided evolution into four subprocesses: (1) division, which creates functional subsystems from the main system; (2) adaptation, where those systems evolve into more efficient versions; (3) inclusion of elements previously excluded from the given systems; and (4) generalization of values, increasing the legitimization of the ever more complex system.

### Technology's Role
Technology is the most important factor in Leslie White's theory, with the notion that social systems are determined by technological systems.(no content)Advancements in the technology of communication translate into advancements in the economic system and political system, distribution of goods, social inequality and other spheres of social life.

## Modern Approaches

More recent approaches focus on changes specific to individual societies and reject the idea that cultures differ primarily according to how far each one has moved along some presumed linear scale of social progress.(no content)Punctuated equilibrium in social theory is a conceptual framework for understanding the process of change in complex social systems, with the theory positing that most social systems exist in an extended period of stasis, which may be punctuated by sudden shifts leading to radical change.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Behavioural ecology at the spatial–social interface". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** This is a **survey** paper - it integrates and reviews existing concepts in spatial and social behavioral ecology rather than proposing new methods or frameworks.

**Triples Extracted:** 9 entities identified from the title and abstract, all classified as "uses" relations (since this is a survey paper):

1. **Spatial Ecology** (concept) - Foundation framework for spatial behavior analysis
2. **Behavioral Ecology** (concept) - Core discipline building understanding of spatial-social interactions
3. **Pathogen Transmission** (task) - Key ecological process affected by spatial-social interfaces
4. **Population Dynamics** (concept) - Influenced by mutual causes and shared consequences
5. **Graph Theory** (method) - Explicitly mentioned approach for integrating processes
6. **Habitat Selection** (concept) - Example of density-dependent spatial-social linkage
7. **Ecological Niche** (concept) - Niche specialization as integrating concept
8. **Migration (ecology)** (concept) - Movement ecology linking spatial-social interface
9. **Social Evolution** (concept) - Outcome of spatial-social interface interactions

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed successfully with correct Wikipedia URLs and proper JSON structure.

Sources:
- [Spatial Ecology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_ecology)
- [Behavioral Ecology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_ecology)
- [Pathogen Transmission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogen_transmission)
- [Population Dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics)
- [Graph Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory)
- [Habitat Selection Hypothesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habitat-selection_hypothesis)
- [Ecological Niche](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_niche)
- [Migration (ecology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Migration_(ecology))
- [Social Evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_evolution)
